## Eastern Philosophical Connections to Tolstoy

Tolstoy was influenced by Eastern philosophy, particularly after reading Schopenhauer's "The World as Will and Representation," becoming "converted to the ascetic morality upheld in that work." He was particularly struck by "the description of Christian, Buddhist, and Hindu ascetic renunciation".

## Chinese Edition

There is a Chinese edition of "Anna Karenina" available, indicating the novel's circulation in Chinese literary circles. The description emphasizes that "A magnificent drama of vengeance, infidelity, and retribution, Anna Karenina portrays the moving story of people whose emotions conflict with the dominant social mores of their time".

## The Novel's Treatment of Adultery

The novel explores adultery as "an almost natural by-product of modern culture" that "threatens the stabilities and foundations upon which society has been built". There is "an inevitability about the tragic fate that hangs over the adulterous love of Anna and Vronsky," with the novel's epigraph being "Vengeance is mine, I will repay." Anna suffers "not so much because she transgresses the moral code but because she refuses to observe the proprieties customarily exacted in such liaisons by the hypocritical high society".

## Broader Context

Eastern religion and philosophy significantly influenced American literature from the nineteenth century onward, with figures like Emerson and Thoreau drawing inspiration from texts like the Bhagavad Gita and Confucian works.
